description: Head and legs are dark green with yellow lines.
Bottom shell is red or orange with unique black pattern.
Top shell varies from olive to brown and is slightly flattened and smooth with red/orange markings along the margin.
Length ranges based on age with a max length of about 10 inches.
habitat: Spend most of their time in shallow, slow-moving water of streams, ponds, lakes, wetlands and rivers; preferably with a soft, muddy bottom with vegetation and submerged logs.
status: A Strategy Species in the Oregon Conservation Strategy (ODFW 2016).
range: Found primarily in the Columbia River Basin, and in the northern portion of the Willamette River Basin.

description: Lacks bright coloration on bottom shell which is usually a creamy yellow with some dark blotches.
Top shell ranges in color from dark brown to olive.
Head and legs are dark brown to olive.
habitat: Inhabits a variety of aquatic habitats, including; ponds, rivers, reservoirs, streams, seasonal wetlands, and flooded gravel pits.
Not fully aquatic; may spend part of the year, including winter months, in upland forests.
May bask on rocks and boulders.
Uses underwater hiding places such as undercut stream banks, mud substrates, logs, and dense patches of aquatic plants to avoid predators.
status: A Strategy Species in the Oregon Conservation Strategy (ODFW 2016).
range: Primarily found west of the Cascades in the Willamette, Umpqua, Rogue, and Klamath River drainages.

description: Greenish grey head commonly with a red patch just behind each eye but some individuals lack the red “ear” stripe.
Top shell dark colored with a black and yellow line pattern, margin edge is serrated.
Bottom shell yellow with black splotches.
Yellow stripes along neck and legs.
habitat: Lives in areas with a calm, warm water source, with lots of aquatic vegetation.
Found in ponds, lakes, creeks, marshes and streams.
Thrives in warm climates, especially the southern United States.
status: Regulated by the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW) as Prohibited Non-Native Wildlife.
Illegal to import/bring into Oregon or possess live without a permit from ODFW.
range: Naturally occurs throughout much of eastern United States.
regulations: Prohibited Non-Native Wildlife in Oregon; permits required (ODFW).
impacts: Use nesting sites similar to native turtles; lay eggs a month earlier, attracting predators to nesting sites.
Grow larger and lay more eggs than Oregon’s native turtles.
Compete with native turtles for food, basking and nesting sites, and cover.
May introduce parasites or diseases to native turtle populations.

description: Oval shell widens toward the back where it is strongly serrated.
Shell color varies from tan/brown to olive to almost black.
Bottom shell (plastron) yellowish, small and cross shaped.
Top of tail has a series of large triangular plates.
Adult shell length about 8–14 inches long and weighs 10–35 lbs.
habitat: Mainly aquatic; prefers warmer, still or slow-moving waterbodies.
Inhabits ponds, lakes, reservoirs, swamps, streams and rivers.
In coast areas they are known to inhabit saltwater marshes.
status: Regulated by the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW) as Prohibited Non-Native Wildlife.
Illegal to import/bring into Oregon or possess live without a permit from ODFW.
range: Native to North America east of the Continental Divide.
regulations: Prohibited Non-Native Wildlife in Oregon; permits required (ODFW).
impacts: Prey on native fish and wildlife including native turtles.
Compete with native turtles for food, basking and nesting sites, and cover.
May introduce parasites or diseases to native turtle populations.

notes: Both of Oregon’s native turtle species are listed as priority at-risk species.
Habitat Loss and Degradation: Development and habitat alterations have severely impacted native turtle populations; turtles need areas with slow moving water and the right vegetation.
Disturbance: Turtles are skittish and easily disturbed by human (and dog) activities.
Removal From the Wild: People take turtles home as pets, even though they don’t make good pets.
